snippet: Busloads of illegal voters, cited by voter fraud groups like True the Vote, have yet to be seen. But that has not deterred such organizations, which widely support conservative causes.
abstract: Efforts to tighten voter requirements have become a major issue in the presidential election. and True the Vote, a national group focused on voter fraud, plans to scrutinize the validity of voter registration rolls and voters who appear at the polls; group claims busloads of illegal voters have been used in past elections , although no evidence of these buses has been found; Catherine Engelbrecht, the group’s leader says the group is nonpartisan, although it grew out of the Tea Party movement.
lead_paragraph: Busloads of illegal voters, cited by voter fraud groups like True the Vote, have yet to be seen. But that has not deterred such organizations, which widely support conservative causes.

headline.seo: Conservative Groups Focus on Registration in Swing States
headline.main: Looking, Very Closely, for Voter Fraud
headline.print_headline: Looking, Very Closely, for Voter Fraud
